title: Fernworthy Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Janine Forbes / Fernworthy Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Fernworthy Reservoir. construction started in 1937 and was completed in 1942. It provides water to Torbay

images.title: Mac Hawkins / Fernworthy reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View of the reservoir dam looking north. Thornworthy Tor is to the left on the horizon.

images.title: Derek Harper / Path by Fernworthy Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The path along the unwooded northern edge of the lake.

images.title: Derek Harper / Fernworthy Reservoir, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Taken from the head of the inlet. Across the water is the picnic area and car park

images.title: Guy Wareham / Fernworthy stone circle
images.caption: Fernworthy stone circle. This fine Bronze Age Stone Circle consists of twenty-seven granite slabs and blocks that stand in a clearing on a plateau of land within Fernworthy Forest. You can find the historic site just to the west of the reservoir.

images.title: A Forest Track in Fernworthy by Tony Atkin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A Forest Track in Fernworthy

images.title: Andrew Hackney / Warren House Inn
images.caption: Warren House Inn. At this point in the day, the sun's angle picks out the painted stonework on the facade. The Two Moors Way can be followed south to reach the historic pub near Water Hill.

images.title: Guy Wareham / Lowton Brook bridge
images.caption: Lowton Brook bridge. A bridge carrying the forest road over Lowton Brook near the south western end of the lake.

description: This walk takes you around the lovely Fernworthy Reservoir and into Fernworthy Forest in Dartmoor. There's a nice waterside path to take you around the reservoir with the option of extending your walk into the adjacent Fernworthy Forest, where you will find miles of delightful woodland trails. It's a really pretty area with a variety of birdlife to look out for on the tranquil waters of the reservoir. You may also see some Dartmoor ponies cooling off in the summer! The area has good facilities with toilets, a catering van and parking on the south side of the reservoir. This walk starts at the car park and takes you along the reservoir and into Fernworthy Forest. You'll also visit the Fernworthy Stone Circle where you will find a Bronze Age circle of 27 granite slabs standing in a clearing on a plateau of land. There are splendid views of Thornworthy Tor and the South Teign River at the eastern end of the reservoir. If you'd like to continue your walk then you could pick up the Two Moors Way which runs through the area. You could follow it south to visit the fascinating Bronze Age settlement at Grimspound. The reservoir is located near Chagford .
